title: SS Empire Burton
text:
Empire Burton was a <a href="CAM%20Ship">CAM Ship</a> which was built in 1941 for the <a href="Ministry%20of%20War%20Transport">Ministry of War Transport</a> (MoWT). Completed in August 1941, she was torpedoed on 20 September 1941 by and sunk.
Description.
"Empire Burton" was built by <a href="Short%20Brothers%20of%20Sunderland">Short Brothers Ltd</a>, <a href="Pallion">Pallion</a> for the MoWT. She was yard number 466. "Empire Burton" was launched on 29 May 1941 and completed in August 1941.
The ship was long, with a beam of and a depth of . She was propelled by a <a href="triple%20expansion%20steam%20engine">triple expansion steam engine</a> which had cylinders of , , and bore by stroke. The engine was built by North East Marine Engine Works, <a href="Newcastle%20upon%20Tyne">Newcastle upon Tyne</a>.
Career.
"Empire Burton" had a short career. She was completed in August 1941 and placed under the management of Common Brothers Ltd, Newcastle upon Tyne. Her port of registry was <a href="Sunderland%2C%20Tyne%20and%20Wear">Sunderland</a>. "Empire Burton" was a member of two convoys.
Convoy ON 9 departed from <a href="Milford%20Haven">Milford Haven</a> on 19 August 1941 and <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> on 20 August. It dispersed at sea on 25 August. "Empire Burton" was bound for <a href="Halifax%20Regional%20Municipality">Halifax</a>, <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>.
Convoy SC 44 departed from Halifax, calling at <a href="Sydney%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Sydney</a> from where the convoy departed on 11 September bound for Liverpool. She was carrying a cargo of of <a href="wheat">wheat</a>. At 01:13 (German time) on 20 September 1941, fired four <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one of which hit "Empire Burton" and sank her with the loss of two of the 60 crew. The ship was east of <a href="Cape%20Farewell%2C%20Greenland">Cape Farewell</a> at the time (). The 58 survivors were rescued by and landed at <a href="Reykjav%C3%ADk">Reykjavík</a>, <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>. Those lost on "Empire Burton" are commemorated at the <a href="Tower%20Hill%20Memorial">Tower Hill Memorial</a>, London.
Official Numbers and Code Letters.
Official Numbers were a forerunner to <a href="IMO%20ship%20identification%20number">IMO Numbers</a>. "Empire Burton" had the United Kingdom Official Number 168915 and used the <a href="Code%20Letters">Code Letters</a> BCMR.
